awd_titl_txt: SBP: The Arizona Youth Project: (Re)defining American Identity and National Belonging
awd_abstract_narration:
How young adults define their social identities has implications for their economic advancement and political participation in our society. This project will investigate how U.S.-born minority and White young adults perceive their identity and status as Americans in the context of rapidly changing economic, demographic, and political conditions. This project will further our understanding of minority and majority integration into U.S. society—particularly among U.S.-born young adults. This research advances the health and welfare of minority and White young adults by understanding how the socio-political local context affects their sense of national identity and belonging. This study will also identify ways to promote political participation in our democracy among young adults. 

The project is a multi-method qualitative study using two research strategies: in-depth interviews, and Photovoice. The sample will consist of U.S.-born young adults between the ages of 18-25 living in five sites in Arizona. We will recruit 60 participants in each of the five sites for a total of 300 participants. Participants will be interviewed twice: once before the 2020 elections and once after the 2020 elections. They will also be asked to participate in a Photovoice project by taking photographs reflecting what they define as American. Interview transcripts, photographs and fieldnotes will be downloaded to a qualitative data analysis software that supports continuous data inputting and analysis, and undergo a three-step coding process. Initial open coding will identify major themes, as well as locality, key political actors, and events. Further coding exercises will flesh out secondary themes and subthemes. A third level of analysis, triangulation, will integrate the data to form a coherent and complete explanation of the overarching research questions.  Findings will inform sociological theories related to ethnic relations, political participation and the transition to adulthood.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Arizona Youth Identity Project is a multimethod and multiwave study focusing on ethnic and racial minority integration into U.S. society, and particularly how different groups perceive their identity, standing, and sense of belonging as members of the nation. Data for this study include an online survey, in-depth interviews, and photovoice. The survey was conducted in September and October 2020, and administered to 1,764 U.S.-born Arizona residents ages 18-30. A subsample of 340 survey respondents reflecting diverse backgrounds, including race/ethnicity, gender, and political affiliation participated in in-depth interviews in October 2020, November 2020 and June 2021. In November 2020, a subsample of 149 interview participants provided photovoice data reflecting their views and concerns about various topics. Results from the survey, interviews and photovoice underscore the connection between race/ethnicity, political beliefs, and American identity. 

Our data show that young adults’ conceptualization of Americanism is mainly tied to the values of liberty and freedom, their sense of duty and responsibility, and the ideal of ethnoracial integration in the nation, although they recognized the continuing racial exclusion of non-whites as Americans. We found that White young adults tend to link citizenship and notions of liberty and freedom to Americanism while Native Americans and Latinos engaged in defensive inclusion as they deemphasize ethnoculturalism and call on their sense of duty and responsibility as well as the ideal of integration to show their Americanness. 

Our findings also show that young adults seem to be moving away from political party affiliation and increasingly identifying as independents due to their discontent and disconnect with the Republican and Democratic parties. Rather than voting along party lines, young adults are issue voters with those voting as Republicans citing conservative values while those voting for Democrats being concerned about social issues. We noted higher rates of voting and social media political activism among young adults and less engagement with other forms of formal and informal political activities. We also found that Native American young adults had a high sense of collectivism and concern for the social and political health of their communities. Our findings can inform best practices for engaging adolescents and young adults in the civic and political life of their communities.   

The timing of our study coincided with the start of the COVID pandemic which allowed us to examine the impact of the pandemic on the lives of young adults and to assess their attitudes and beliefs about the vaccine and factors associated with vaccine hesitancy. We found that young adults in rural areas of Arizona have similar reasons for hesitancy as many rural populations across the country, particularly a distrust of science and government. However, they have more persuasive reasons for vaccine acceptability. The disproportionate impact of the pandemic, particularly among Native populations, and the resultant desire to get back to normal, strongly influenced rural young adults in Arizona. Additionally, not a single rural resident in our sample cited inaccessibility as a reason for rejecting the vaccine, reflecting the benefits of active mobile vaccination campaigns. These findings illuminate the importance of investigating the nuances of attitudes across rural populations to better understand and address the factors associated with vaccine uptake among young adults. 

In addition to scholarly contributions, our project provided extensive qualitative research training to 60+ undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, many of whom are ethnic/racial minorities, first generation-college, and/or women. These students learned to collect and analyze qualitative data and to work collaboratively as part of a large team. About a dozen students continued their involvement in the project, allowing them to further their training to include presenting papers and posters at conferences, and drafting papers to be submitted for publication. Through this project, we have helped students develop research skills as well as professional and communication skills that can translate into their professional and civic lives.
